content: The "Harmful Algal Blooms and Hypoxia Amendments Act of 2008" includes sections on amending the Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Research and Control Act of 1998, findings, purpose, interagency task force, national program, regional plans, reporting, pilot program, interagency financing, application with other laws, and definitions. The Harmful Algal Blooms and Hypoxia Amendments Act of 2008 amends the Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Research and Control Act of 1998. Amendments or repeals in the Act refer to sections of the 1998 Act. Section 602 is amended to address the impact of harmful algal blooms and hypoxia on coastal economies, emphasizing the need for integrated research and control strategies to mitigate nutrient loading from various sources. The United States seafood and tourism industries suffer annual losses of $82 million due to harmful algal blooms. Global climate change may impact the increase or decrease of harmful algal blooms and hypoxic events in US waters, necessitating regional coordination for research and mitigation efforts. The Hypoxia Research and Control Act of 1998 has led to technological advances in remote sensing, molecular tools, satellite imagery, and ocean observing systems. These advancements improve monitoring, prediction, and decision-making tools for managers and stakeholders. The Act is amended to include a new section 602A with specified purposes. The Act is amended to include a new section 602A with specified purposes to address harmful algal blooms, hypoxia, and nuisance algae through research, monitoring, prevention, and response plans at regional, State, and local levels. The Act is amended to establish an Interagency Task Force on Harmful Algal Blooms and Hypoxia. The Act is amended to establish an Interagency Task Force on Harmful Algal Blooms and Hypoxia. The Task Force will consist of representatives from various federal departments and agencies, with specific amendments made to the composition of federal and state representatives. The Act is amended to establish an Interagency Task Force on Harmful Algal Blooms and Hypoxia. Amendments include criteria for selecting state representatives on a rotating basis for 2-year terms, and changes to the frequency of assessments to be conducted. The Act is amended to establish an Interagency Task Force on Harmful Algal Blooms and Hypoxia. The amendments include changes to the frequency of assessments, such as removing specific time intervals and replacing them with more general language. The Act is amended to establish a National Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Program under section 603A. The President, through the Task Force, will establish a national program for addressing harmful algal blooms and hypoxia. The Task Force will oversee the program's development and implementation, coordinating interagency efforts, reviewing spending plans, distributing grants, and supporting regional research and action plans. The National Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Program, overseen by the Task Force, aims to support the development of institutional mechanisms, expedite interagency reviews, promote new technologies, and implement a national strategy to address harmful algal blooms and hypoxia events. NOAA is the lead Federal agency for this program. The National Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Program, overseen by the Task Force, aims to plan, coordinate, and implement activities to address harmful algal blooms and hypoxia events. The Program administers grant funding, coordinates NOAA programs, and reports to the Task Force via the Administrator. The National Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Program, overseen by the Task Force, coordinates NOAA programs, collaborates with other government agencies, supports international efforts, and conducts outreach and education programs to address harmful algal blooms and hypoxia. The National Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Program coordinates programs to improve public education, awareness, and training for monitoring and mitigating harmful algal blooms and hypoxia. Regional efforts are supported through communication of research plans and online data portals for stakeholders. The National Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Program oversees the development, review, and updating of Regional Research and Action Plans. It convenes an annual meeting of the Task Force and maintains programs related to harmful algal blooms and monitoring. The National Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Program oversees various programs, including the Mitigation and Control of Harmful Algal Blooms Program, aimed at preventing, mitigating, and controlling harmful algal blooms through research and strategies development. The National Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Program aims to develop technology to mitigate harmful algal blooms and work cooperatively with other agencies and organizations to manage data and infrastructure. The National Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Program focuses on developing technology to mitigate harmful algal blooms and collaborating with other agencies to manage data and infrastructure, including creating data portals and communication routes for data dissemination and management tools. SEC. 7. REGIONAL RESEARCH AND ACTION PLANS. The Act, as amended by section 6, includes a new section 602B for Regional Research and Action Plans. The Program oversees the development of Regional Research and Action Plans and identifies regions to be addressed. Regional Panels of Experts are convened every 5 years with officials from various sectors to address harmful algal blooms and hypoxia. The Regional Panels of Experts include public health officials, emergency management officials, NGOs, science and technology institutions, economists, affected industries, scientists, and other stakeholders. They develop Regional Research and Action Plans addressing harmful algal blooms and hypoxia, including baseline research. The curr_chunk discusses the need for research on harmful algal blooms and hypoxia, including understanding the conditions causing them, regional priorities, technology development, and government actions to prevent and control them. The curr_chunk focuses on reducing harmful algal blooms and hypoxia during emergencies, addressing human health impacts, and protecting vulnerable ecosystems affected by these issues.
